taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013
IUCN Red List (Species Assessed for Global Conservation)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Despite its enormous size, rivalling the Mekong giant catfish as largest freshwater fish in the world, the giant freshwater stingray is elusive and understudied. It is thought to mature at around 110 cm across and gives birth to live young of 30 cm across (4). It is venomous but uses its sting in self-defence as it preys upon invertebrates and relatively small fish (2).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Description
dataObjects.description: Awe-inspiringly large, the giant freshwater stingray lives up to its name, possessing a venomous sting and a large whip-like tail (2). It is brown on the upper surface of its broad, thin, disc-shaped body, and paler beneath with a ring of black around the edge. It has a large snout but small eyes (3).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Inhabits sandy bottoms in estuaries and large rivers (Ref. 12693).  Feeds on benthic invertebrates (Ref. 12693) and fishes (Ref. 32457).  Ovoviviparous (Ref. 50449).  Caught occasionally by demersal gillnet and longline fisheries operating in riverine and estuarine areas. Utilized for its meat and possibly its cartilage (Ref.58048). Marketed fresh, with large individuals being sold in cut pieces by the kilogram (Ref. 12693).  Size reaches to about 500 cm TL.  Threatened due to over harvesting and pollution (Ref. 58490).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Western Pacific: Breakish estuaries and freshwataers of large rivers; Thailand, Borneo, northern Australia, southern New Guinea.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range
dataObjects.description: Thought to occur in most large rivers of tropical Australia, as well as the Fly River basin, New Guinea, the Mahakam River basin, Borneo and several rivers in Thailand (4).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Absence of ventral and dorsal skin folds on the tail, and the broad greyish to blackish marginal band on the ventral surface of the disc.  The dorsal surface of the disc is brown (Ref. 27732).  Spiral valve with 21 turns; dorsal surface with uniform brown or grey coloration (Ref. 12693).  Lacking caudal fin; with long whip-like tail (Ref. 43281).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Habitat
dataObjects.description: Inhabits the sandy bottoms of large rivers and estuaries (1).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObjects.title: Status
dataObjects.description: The giant freshwater stingray is classified as Vulnerable (VU A1bcde + 2ce) on the IUCN Red List (1).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.title: Threats
dataObjects.description: In 1992, Thai fisherman reported having caught 25 individuals, but the following year this figure fell to just three, hinting at a rapid decline (4). Threats in Thailand are from poor habitat management, including the destruction of the forest canopy which leads to drought upstream and flooding downstream during the monsoon, as well as dam building which prevents migratory fish breeding successfully, and therefore reduces available prey. In Australia the main threat to this species is thought to be silt from uranium mines which contains heavy metals and radio-isotopes. However, it is not known how threatening this is to these fish (4). Throughout its range, the giant freshwater stingray is at risk from both direct and incidental fishing, habitat destruction and range fragmentation leading to inbreeding depression (2).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Management
dataObjects.title: Conservation
dataObjects.description: Further research into this incredible fish's biology and status is necessary. The Australian government plan to form a national recovery team who will attempt to compile information on the distribution, abundance and ecology of the giant freshwater stingray (4).
